Catalytic biomass conversion is a crucial pathway for high-value utilization of renewable resources, yet current catalysts face limitations such as insufficient acid sites, poor product selectivity, and low cycling stability. This study developed a magnetic tin-based solid acid catalyst (Fe3O4@PDA-Sn) using 5-sulfoisophthalic acid sodium salt as a ligand and dopamine hydrochloride-coated Fe3O4 for targeted catalytic conversion of sugarcane bagasse. Results demonstrated that the catalyst achieved a furfural yield of 86.2% and a levulinic acid yield of 32.5% at 170°C for 90 min, with FT-IR, NMR, and XRD confirming its differential deconstruction capability toward cellulose and hemicellulose. Mechanistic analysis demonstrated that the coordinated interaction between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites played a crucial role in steering the reaction toward specific pathways: hemicellulose hydrolysis products underwent dehydration to furfural (enriched in the organic phase), while cellulose was selectively cleaved to form levulinic acid. The catalyst maintained stable performance over 5 cycles without regeneration, with 97.3% magnetic recovery efficiency, offering a novel "facile magnetic separation–excellent cycling performance" strategy for hierarchical biomass conversion. This work provides critical insights into the design of multifunctional biorefinery catalysts for sustainable biomass valorization. Introduction Sugarcane bagasse, the primary by-product of the sugar industry, is composed mainly of cellulose (∼40-50%), hemicellulose (20-30%), and lignin (20-25%) [1]. Due to its high carbohydrate content and renewability, bagasse represents a promising feedstock for producing high-value-added chemicals. The hemicellulose and cellulose fractions can be converted into furfural (FF) and levulinic acid (LA), respectively—two versatile platform molecules for the biofuel, pharmaceutical, and polymer industries [2]. The efficient utilization of sugarcane bagasse aligns with the principles of biorefinery and green development, not only mitigating the environmental pollution caused by this agricultural waste but also contributing to the goals of carbon neutrality and sustainable development. Despite its great potential, the efficient valorization of sugarcane bagasse is hindered by several critical challenges. First, the three main components are intricately interlinked, forming a recalcitrant barrier that resists deconstruction and complicates the conversion of its constituents [3]. Second, conventional processes like homogeneous acid-catalyzed hydrolysis, while effective for biomass deconstruction, suffer from inherent drawbacks such as severe equipment corrosion, complex product separation, and the generation of large volumes of acidic wastewater [4]. Furthermore, many current conversion strategies selectively target a single component, for instance, converting only hemicellulose to furfural or cellulose to levulinic acid. This approach diminishes the overall utilization efficiency of the lignocellulosic biomass and restricts its economic viability [5–7]. To overcome these challenges, significant research efforts have been undertaken. Solid acid catalysts, including zeolites, metal oxides, and sulfonated carbons, have been developed as alternatives to homogeneous acids. Among these, biomass-derived carbon-based solid acids have garnered considerable attention owing to their tunable acidity, high stability, and low cost [7–9]. However, the effective recovery of solid catalysts post-reaction remains a key bottleneck for their industrial application. Magnetically recoverable solid acid catalysts, fabricated by incorporating magnetic components like Fe3O4, have emerged as an attractive solution to this problem [10]. More importantly, designing a single catalyst capable of the simultaneous conversion of both hemicellulose and cellulose would fundamentally address the issue of low feedstock utilization. While literature has shown that solid acids are effective for the individual conversions of hemicellulose to furfural and cellulose to levulinic acid, reports on single catalysts that can efficiently achieve this synchronous process—particularly magnetically recoverable ones—remain scarce. Herein, we report the design and fabrication of a magnetically recoverable, tin-based solid acid for the one-pot, simultaneous conversion of hemicellulose and cellulose from sugarcane bagasse into furfural and levulinic acid under hydrothermal conditions. This work integrates efficient component separation, selective catalytic conversion, and facile catalyst recovery into a unified process. The proposed strategy not only pioneers a new pathway for the high-value valorization of sugarcane bagasse but also provides novel insights into the design of multifunctional solid acid catalysts and their integration into advanced biorefinery schemes. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Sugarcane bagasse supplied by the Guangzhou Institute of Energy Research (Guangzhou, China) was thoroughly washed several times with deionized water at room temperature to remove residual free sugars and water-soluble components. It was then oven-dried at 80°C until constant weight and finally ground to pass through 40 and 60 mesh sieves before use. Before application, it underwent Soxhlet extraction for 6 h using a 2:1 (v/v) acetone-ethanol solvent system to remove waxes and other contaminants. The dewaxed sugarcane bagasse primarily consisted of cellulose at 43.0 wt%, hemicellulose at 28.8 wt% (of which xylose accounted for 25.8 wt% and arabinose for 3.02 wt%), and lignin at 18.3 wt%. Furfural and levulinic acid, both with purities exceeding 99.0% as determined by HPLC, were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Analytical-grade SnCl4·5H2O (≥99.0%) was procured from Chengdu Grecian Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. Additional chemicals, including ferric chloride hexahydrate, anhydrous sodium acetate, ethylene glycol, and N, N-dimethylformamide, were procured from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (molecular weight 8000) and dopamine hydrochloride (PDA, AR, ≥98%) were provided by Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., sodium chloride (NaCl, analytical reagent, purity ≥99.5%) along with dichloromethane (DCM), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF), and other chemicals of comparable purity were supplied by Tianjin Kemer Chemical Reagent Co. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst 2.2.1 Synthesis of magnetic nanomaterials based on Fe3O4 Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were prepared using a solvent-assisted hydrothermal technique [11]. First, 1.50 g of FeCl3·6H2O, 1.0 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, with a molecular weight of 8000), and 2.0 g of anhydrous sodium acetate were completely dissolved into 30 mL of ethylene glycol. To achieve a uniform mixture, the solution was treated with ultrasound for 30 min. Subsequently, the uniform mixture was loaded into a Teflon-lined autoclave with a capacity of 50 mL and maintained under static conditions at 200°C for 10 h. Following the autoclaving, the mixture was allowed to reach ambient temperature, after which the Fe3O4 product was collected using a magnetic separator. To remove residual impurities, the material underwent triple rinsing with deionized water. Subsequently, it was vacuum-dried at 60°C for 12 h before use. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Fe3O4@PDA A quantity of 100 milligrams of Fe3O4 nanoparticles was introduced into 50 mL of Tris buffer solution (0.05 molar, pH 8.5) containing 100 milligrams of dopamine hydrochloride (PDA). The resulting mixture was agitated at 25°C for 12 h to synthesize Fe3O4@PDA. After the reaction had concluded, the Fe3O4@PDA particles were magnetically isolated. Subsequently, the particles underwent three successive washes with deionized water, followed by three washes using ethanol. Before further application, drying was performed in a vacuum oven at 60°C for 12 h. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Fe3O4@PDA-Sn A mixture was prepared by combining 1.227 g of tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate and 1.408 g of sodium 5-sulfonatoisophthalate in 53 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide. This combination was agitated for 15 min. After that, 173 milligrams of Fe3O4@PDA were introduced into the solution, and the stirring continued for another 15 min. The prepared solution was loaded into a 100 mL autoclave made of stainless steel and lined with polytetrafluoroethylene. The system was brought up to 105°C and held steady at this temperature for 20 h. After completion of the heating cycle, it could naturally cool to ambient temperature. After reaching room temperature, the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst was separated using a magnetic field. Subsequently, the separated catalyst underwent a washing procedure. The material underwent three successive rinses using N, N-dimethylformamide, deionized water, and ethanol. After completing the washing procedure, drying was carried out in a vacuum oven maintained at 60°C for 12 h. The synthesized material was given the name Fe3O4@PDA-Sn. For comparative analysis, Fe3O4@PDA was also synthesized under similar conditions. 2.3 Preparation of furfural and levulinic acid (LA) from sugarcane bagasse The reaction mixtures contained sugarcane bagasse at a solid-to-liquid ratio of 1:20 (g/mL) and were heated to 170°C for 90 min. All reactions were conducted within a 25 mL reactor lined with Teflon. The sugarcane bagasse, catalyst, and selected liquid phase-either aqueous or organic-were mixed according to predetermined ratios and loaded into the reaction vessel. Subsequently, heating was applied until reaching the target temperature. Upon completion, rapid cooling was performed using an ice-water bath. Then, phase separation was conducted to isolate the liquid from the remaining solids. The residue was rinsed with deionized water and oven-dried at 80°C for 12 h. Magnetic separation was used to extract the catalyst from the reaction residue. In biphasic reaction systems, a separatory funnel was utilized to separate the aqueous and organic layers. Liquid fractions were pretreated by filtration through a 0.22 μm membrane syringe to eliminate insoluble impurities before analysis. 2.4 Analysis of Reactants and Products 2.4.1 Quantitative Analysis of Reaction Solution High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was employed to quantify the liquid-phase products, utilizing a Waters 1515 isocratic pump coupled with a 2412 refractive index detector (Waters, USA). Furfural quantification utilized an Eclipse XDB-C18 column (Aminex, USA) held at 30°C. A mixture of acetonitrile and water (15:85, v/v) served as the mobile phase, delivered at a constant flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. For levulinic acid (LA) detection, separation was conducted using a BIO-RAD HPX-87H column maintained at 60 °C, with 5 mM H2SO4 as the eluent at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. The yields of furfural and levulinic acid were determined by the mole ratio of the produced furfural to the xylose in hemicellulose and the produced levulinic acid to the glucose in the sugarcane bagasse, respectively. Product yields were determined using the following equation: (1) Furfural yield ( % ) = moles of furfural in the product ( mol ) moles of initial xylose ( mol ) × 100 % (2) LA yield ( % ) = moles of furfural in the product ( mol ) moles of initial glucose ( mol ) × 100 % 2.4.2 Characterization of the solid residue The composition of sugarcane bagasse in its raw and processed states was analyzed following the procedures developed by NREL (National Renewable Energy Laboratory). FTIR spectroscopy was conducted on both untreated and treated samples using a TENSOR27 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) to identify functional groups. Surface microstructures were examined by SEM. A JSM-6490-LV instrument from Japan was used at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. For both types of sugarcane bagasse, XRD analyses were performed on a Bruker diffractometer (Germany). Cu Kα radiation was utilized to evaluate the crystallinity. Moreover, solid-state NMR spectroscopy, specifically a Bruker Avance 400 III HD system (Bruker Corp., Billerica, MA, USA), was employed to study the structural characteristics. The crystallinity index (CrI) was computed according to the following equation: (3) GrI = ( I 002 − I a m ) / I 002 Where I002 is the scattering intensity of cellulose at 2θ = 21.7° and I am is the intensity of the amorphous part of the residue at 2θ = 17.5°. 2.5 Catalyst characterization TEM (JEOL 2010) was utilized to characterize the internal structure of the catalysts, while SEM (JSM-6490-LV, Japan) provided insights into their surface morphology. Elemental distribution and composition were analyzed by EDX on the same SEM system with an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. After the catalyst samples were finely ground and pretreated under vacuum at 200°C for one h, Py-IR spectra were obtained using a Nicolet 710 FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet, Madison, WI, USA). TPD measurements were carried out on a BelCata-II multifunctional adsorption instrument from Japan, which was equipped with an online TCD. Elemental analysis via XPS was conducted using a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. A Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer was used for the relevant analysis. Moreover, the magnetic behavior of the samples was assessed by a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM 7410, Lakeshore, Colchester, USA). 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Effect of catalytic systems on furfural yields Furfural was first produced from sugarcane bagasse using different catalytic systems. The outcomes are presented in Table1. In the single-phase system, with water as the only reaction medium and without adding NaCl aqueous solution or catalyst, the furfural yield was merely 14.4% (Table 1, entry 1). Introducing the catalyst under these conditions caused the yield to decrease to 10.6% (Table 1, entry). This reduction is primarily attributed to side reactions of furfural occurring in the acidic hydrothermal environment. However, employing an aqueous NaCl solution as the reaction medium significantly enhanced furfural production, increasing the yield to 34.7% (Table 1, entry 3). This improvement suggests that NaCl aids in converting xylose to furfural. Presumably, the Cl- ions play a catalytic part, boosting enolization and the subsequent dehydration steps [12]. When a catalyst was introduced into the system, the furfural yield declined to 23.7% (Table 1, entry 4). This decrease was associated with the active catalytic sites, which not only sped up furfural degradation but also promoted the generation of by-products like aldehydes and carboxylic acids [13]. Moreover, replacing water with dichloromethane (DCM) as the solvent resulted in a furfural yield of 25.4% (Table 1, entry 9), implying that organic solvents are advantageous in improving furfural yield by suppressing its further degradation and undesired condensation reactions [14]. The furfural yields were 54.1% and 12.1% in the NaCl/2-MTHF and NaCl/DMSO biphasic systems (Table 1, entries 5 and 6), respectively. Under identical reaction conditions, the NaCl/2-MTHF biphasic system exhibited better performance compared to the NaCl/DMSO system. This increased efficiency is largely attributed to the effective transfer of furfural into the 2-MTHF organic phase. This reduces its contact with the aqueous NaCl environment, thereby inhibiting further degradation. In contrast, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), a highly polar solvent, undergoes additional oxidation with furfural during its formation, producing formic acid and other organic acid compounds [15]. The furfural production efficiency of the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst was evaluated under various reaction conditions. Among the tested systems, the combination of NaCl and DCM in a 1:1 ratio yielded the highest furfural output, reaching 58.1% in the presence of the catalyst (Table 1, entry 7). In contrast, when no catalyst was introduced into the NaCl/DCM (1:1) biphasic system, the furfural yield declined to 39.6% (Table 1, entry 8). These findings demonstrate that introducing Fe3O4@PDA-Sn notably boosts the conversion efficiency of xylose to furfural. Furthermore, the influence of different volume ratios of NaCl to DCM on product yield was systematically examined, as summarized in Table 1 (entries 10-13). The yield of furfural was 51.5% and 54.3% when the volume ratio of NaCl to DCM was 4:6 and 6:4, respectively. This variation stems from the higher proportion of the aqueous NaCl phase, which triggers a side reaction that impedes the efficient and rapid transfer of furfural into the DCM phase. Conversely, as the DCM percentage rises and the aqueous NaCl phase proportion falls, the acidic sites in the NaCl phase, which are crucial for dissolving xylose from hemicellulose at high temperatures, decrease. This hurts furfural production [16]. Therefore, a NaCl/DCM volume ratio of 1:1 was selected for the subsequent reaction system. 3.2 Effects of reaction conditions on furfural and LA yields The influence of catalyst dosage on furfural yield is illustrated in Fig. 1 a. When the substrate amount was 0.1 g, increasing the catalyst quantity from 0.01 g to 0.03 g led to an increase in furfural yield from 51.5% to 69.4%. This indicates that more acidic sites facilitate furfural formation. However, excessively acidic sites accelerate side reactions, causing product condensation, degradation, and increased humic substances, which reduce the yield [17]. Additionally, as depicted in Fig. 1b, when using 0.03 g of catalyst, increasing the substrate concentration from 0.01 g to 0.12 g improved the furfural yield from 12.4% to 72.4%. Increasing the substrate further, up to 0.15 g, caused the yield to drop to 60.2%. Presumably, this is because more molecular collisions occur, resulting in product self-condensation or cross-polymerization with reactants [18]. Thus, under the conditions of 170°C for 2 h, with 0.03 g of Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst and 0.12 g of sugarcane bagasse in a NaCl/DCM solvent system with a 1:1 volume ratio, the highest furfural yield of 72.4% was achieved. The effects of varying temperature and reaction duration on the catalyst-driven transformation of sugarcane bagasse into furfural were evaluated, as shown in Fig. 1c. At 160°C and 120 min, the furfural yield was relatively low at 54.7%. Raising the temperature to 170°C significantly increased the yield, reaching a maximum of 86.2%, with hemicellulose in sugarcane bagasse fully converted within 90 min. However, further elevation of the temperature and prolonged reaction times caused the formation of degradation by-products and insoluble residues [19]. Interestingly, apart from the transformation of sugarcane bagasse into furfural, levulinic acid, a crucial platform chemical originating from cellulose, was also detected. Since cellulose has higher thermal stability than hemicellulose, it is hypothesized that under hydrothermal conditions, the solid-acid catalyst first facilitates the conversion of hemicellulose into furfural. Subsequently, the impact of reaction temperature and duration on the conversion of cellulose to levulinic acid was further investigated. As shown in Fig. 1d, at 160°C for 210 min, the yield of levulinic acid was 52%. At 170°C for 150 min, the yield increased to 55.3%, and at 180°C for 90 min, it reached a maximum of 60.2%. As the temperature increased, the required reaction time decreased, leading to higher levulinic acid yields. However, further increases in temperature and reaction time caused a significant drop in levulinic acid yield. This decline is due to the formation of more humic substances and other by-products at higher temperatures. Additionally, longer reaction times lead to increased char deposition on the catalyst, resulting in catalyst degradation and deactivation [20]. Based on the optimal parameters for converting hemicellulose to furfural, the reaction was conducted at 170 °C for 90 min. Using 0.03 g of catalyst and 0.12 g of sugarcane bagasse as the substrate under these conditions, the maximum furfural yield reached 86.2% (relative to theoretical pentose content in hemicellulose), while the levulinic acid yield was 32.5% (relative to theoretical hexose content in cellulose). To showcase the efficacy of the synthesized solid-acid catalyst in the hydrothermal conversion of sugarcane bagasse to furfural and levulinic acid, a comparative analysis was carried out, referencing previously reported catalytic conversions of various biomass feedstocks. As shown in Table 2 , high yields can be obtained from the individual conversion of hemicellulose or cellulose: furfural yields can reach as high as 87.80% (Entry 3), while levulinic acid yields can reach up to 41.09% (Entry 5). However, when both furfural and levulinic acid are produced simultaneously, their yields fall to 56.75% and 18.88%, respectively (Entry 6), which are significantly lower than those achieved with the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst reported in this study. These results highlight the superior directional depolymerization capability of the synthesized catalyst for both hemicellulose and cellulose under hydrothermal conditions. This performance is due to the existence of active catalytic sites, such as –SO3H, –COOH, –OH groups, and SnOX species. 3.3 Characteristics of catalyst Fig. 2 systematically illustrates the synthesis route, morphology, and elemental composition of the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn magnetic solid acid catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2a, the catalyst preparation involved a three-step process. Initially, spherical Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles were synthesized via a solvothermal method. Subsequently, through the self-polymerization of dopamine in an alkaline Tris buffer, a polydopamine (PDA) coating was generated, resulting in the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn intermediate. Finally, in a DMF solvent, SnCl4·5H2O and 5-sulfoisophthalic acid were coordinated to incorporate Sn species and multiple acidic functional groups, giving rise to the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn composite catalyst featuring both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image in Fig. 2b reveals that the catalyst exhibits a quasi-spherical morphology with a uniform particle size distribution and a rough surface, enhancing surface area and active site exposure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in Fig. 2c further confirms the core–shell structure, where a PDA layer encapsulates Fe3O4 cores, and nanoscale Sn species are evenly distributed on the outer surface, enabling spatial dispersion of multiphase active sites. The EDS spectra in Fig. 2d show the presence of C, O, Fe, S, and Sn in Fe3O4@PDA-Sn. The enhanced Sn signal verifies the successful addition of tin, and the detected sulfur suggests that sulfonic acid groups were effectively attached to the catalyst surface. The magnetic behavior of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@PDA, and Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalysts was investigated using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). As illustrated in Fig. 3 , pure Fe3O4 particles exhibited the strongest saturation magnetization, highlighting their superior intrinsic magnetic characteristics. Following surface modification with polydopamine (PDA), the magnetization of Fe3O4@PDA decreased, yet it remained sufficiently strong to allow efficient magnetic separation and retained notable catalytic activity. Further functionalization with Sn species led to a more pronounced decline in saturation magnetization for the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn composite. Nevertheless, its magnetic response was still adequate for practical separation and catalytic use. These results demonstrate that surface functionalization can significantly alter the magnetic behavior of Fe3O4 nanoparticles. Importantly, despite the reduced magnetization, the synthesized catalysts still fulfill the dual requirements of magnetic recoverability and catalytic efficiency. The pyridine-adsorbed FTIR (Py-IR) spectra of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@PDA, and Fe3O4@PDA-Sn, as presented in Fig. 4 , provide useful insights into the type and strength of acid sites on the catalyst surfaces. Distinct absorption peaks were observed at 1445, 1489, and 1596 cm-1. The absorption bands at 1445 cm-1 and 1596 cm-1 are associated with pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites. Meanwhile, the signal at 1489 cm-1 indicates that pyridine is interacting with both Brønsted and Lewis acid functionalities simultaneously. Notably, Fe3O4@PDA-Sn exhibited substantially stronger absorption at all three positions compared to Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@PDA, indicating a higher density of both types of acid sites on its surface. This increase is largely due to the addition of tin species and the functional modification by 5-sulfoisophthalic acid, which together lead to a higher density of surface acid sites. These findings affirm the pronounced bifunctional acidic character of the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to investigate the surface elemental composition and chemical states of the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst, as shown in Fig. 5 and detailed in Table 3 . In the high-resolution C 1s spectrum of Fe3O4@PDA-Sn (Fig. 5a), the emergence of peaks corresponding to C–Sn (287.9 eV) and C–O–Sn (288.6 eV) bonds, alongside the inherent C–C/C=C and C–O peaks of the PDA support, provides strong evidence for the covalent anchoring of Sn species [25,26]. The deconvolution of the high-resolution O 1s spectrum (Fig. 5b) reveals four component peaks centered at 531.2, 531.8, 532.4, and 533.1 eV, which are assigned to C–O, –SO3H, C=O, and O–Sn/C–O–Sn, respectively [25,27]. The definitive presence of the –SO3H peak corroborates the introduction of sulfonic acid functionalities, while the combination of these oxygen-based moieties indicates an enrichment of surface oxygen-containing groups. The Sn 3d spectrum (Fig. 5c) shows two pairs of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks at 486.5/495.0 eV and 487.2/495.7 eV, corresponding to the coexistence of Sn2+ and Sn4+ oxidation states, suggesting that multivalent SnOX species contribute Lewis acid sites [25]. The survey XPS spectrum (Fig. 5d) displays prominent signals for Sn 3d and S 2p, corroborating the findings from the high-resolution scans and providing further evidence for the incorporation of both tin and sulfonic acid moieties. Quantitative XPS analysis (Table 3) reveals that the surface of Fe3O4@PDA-Sn is composed of 12.63% Sn, 0.66% S, and 39.94% O (atomic content). This elemental composition confirms the incorporation of tin species (as Lewis acid sources) and sulfonic acid groups (as Brønsted acid sources), thereby establishing the formation of dual-acid active sites. Fig. 6 displays the NH3-TPD profiles of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@PDA, and Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalysts, which are utilized to assess the strength and distribution of their acidic sites. All three catalysts exhibited NH3 desorption peaks across different temperature regions, corresponding to weak (<200 °C), medium (200–400 °C), and strong (>400 °C) acid sites. Among them, Fe3O4@PDA-Sn showed the highest desorption intensity over the entire temperature range, with a particularly prominent peak at 625 °C, indicating many thermally stable, strong acid sites. Additionally, compared with Fe3O4, which exhibited a maximum desorption peak at 542 °C with a total acidity of only 1.41 mmol/g, the total acid amounts of Fe3O4@PDA and Fe3O4@PDA-Sn increased significantly to 6.50 mmol/g and 8.78 mmol/g, respectively. This enhancement is primarily attributed to the introduction of Brønsted acid sites such as –SO3H and –COOH, and the synergistic contribution of SnOX nanoparticles providing Lewis acid sites. Therefore, Fe3O4@PDA-Sn possesses a higher total acidity and broader acid site distribution, which are beneficial for the efficient cleavage of C5/C6 sugars and selective formation of target products during biomass catalytic conversion. The durability and recyclability of the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst was evaluated through multiple reaction cycles under optimal conditions. After each reaction, an external magnet was used to recover the catalyst. It was then rinsed thoroughly with ultrapure water and absolute ethanol, and subsequently dried at 80°C for reuse, as illustrated in Fig. 7 a. In the initial run, furfural and levulinic acid were obtained at yields of 87.6% and 32.6%, respectively. However, with successive cycles, a gradual decline in product yields was observed. By the fifth reuse, furfural and levulinic acid yields had decreased by 16.5% and 25.6%, respectively. The relatively lower yield of levulinic acid compared to furfural is likely associated with the high crystallinity of cellulose, which limits its reactivity under the given conditions. To assess its heterogeneity and reusability, the Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst was subjected to five consecutive reaction cycles. The catalyst demonstrated excellent recoverability, maintaining a mass recovery of approximately 97.3% after the fifth cycle (Fig. 7b). The minor mass loss (from an initial 0.150 g to a final 0.146 g) is attributed to washing and the loss of fine particles [27,28]. In the hysteresis loop measurement (Fig. 3), although the saturation magnetization of Fe3O4@PDA-Sn was reduced, its magnetism was still sufficient to meet the practical needs of magnetic recovery. While the magnetic core is catalytically inert, it ensures efficient recovery, reinforcing the system's practical recyclability. These results demonstrate that despite a minor decline in catalytic activity—likely due to carbon deposition or partial site deactivation—the catalyst maintains its structural integrity and heterogeneous nature, allowing for effective recycling. 3.4 Characteristics of solid residue Fig. 8 a illustrates the process of converting sugarcane bagasse into furfural (FF) and levulinic acid (LA) under hydrothermal conditions, catalyzed by the magnetic solid acid Fe3O4@PDA-Sn. The surface morphology of the sugarcane bagasse before and after the reaction is presented in Fig. 8b-d. As shown in Fig. 8b, the untreated sugarcane bagasse exhibits a relatively smooth, intact, and ordered surface structure. In contrast, after the hydrothermal reaction catalyzed by the solid acid, the surface of the solid residue becomes rough, displaying wrinkles and porous features (Fig. 8c and 8d). This change in morphology is attributed to the conversion and/or dissolution of hemicellulose and cellulose from the bagasse during the acidic hydrothermal treatment [29]. Fig. 9 presents the FTIR analysis of sugarcane bagasse samples both prior to and following treatment. The absorption bands measured at 3417 cm-1 and 2901 cm-1 are assigned to the O-H stretching vibrations and the aliphatic C-H stretching vibrations, respectively. These originate from the cellulose or hemicellulose in the sugarcane bagasse [30]. The band detected at 1373 cm-1 is associated with the C-H bending vibration typical of the hemicellulose structure [31]. The absorption bands at 1730 cm-1 and 1259 cm-1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of glyoxylate and acetyl groups in hemicellulose, respectively. After hydrothermal treatment, these peaks significantly weaken or vanish, indicating cleavage of ester bonds and the partial removal or conversion of hemicellulose [32]. consistent with its effective transformation to furfural under these conditions. The absorption peak at 1635 cm-1 corresponds to adsorbed water, while the intense band at 1455 cm-1 is associated with C-N stretching vibrations [33]. The band at 1511 cm-1 reflects vibrations of the aromatic lignin backbone, suggesting that lignin remains largely in the solid residue [3]. In the 1200–1000 cm-1 range, the absorption bands are due to the C-O-C stretching vibrations of the β-(1,4)-glycosidic linkages in cellulose. A reduction in peak intensity here after treatment implies partial cleavage of glycosidic bonds or a decrease in the cellulose amorphous region during hydrothermal processing [34]. The sharp peak at 894 cm-1, related to the glycosidic bonds connecting sugar units in hemicellulose, diminishes after treatment. This indicates partial degradation or removal of certain hemicellulose components [35]. Solid-state CP/MAS 13C NMR analysis indicated that the variations in chemical shifts of sugarcane bagasse and its hydrothermally treated counterpart reflect structural changes, as illustrated in Fig. 10 . In sugarcane bagasse, the signal observed at 171.9 ppm is assigned to the carbonyl carbons found in carboxylic acids and ester groups, while the peak at 126.9 ppm corresponds to carbons in the aromatic rings of lignin as well as the β-O-4 linkages present in syringyl units [36]. Signals at 104.3 ppm and 88.4 ppm are attributed to the crystalline C1 and C4 carbons of cellulose, respectively. Peaks appearing at 84.1 ppm and 72.3 ppm represent the C4, C2, C3, and C5 carbons found in both hemicellulose and cellulose. The resonance at 65.1 ppm indicates C6 carbons in cellulose, and the peak at 21.5 ppm is related to methyl carbons within aliphatic compounds. In the treated sugarcane bagasse, the peaks at 171.9 ppm and 126.9 ppm weaken, indicating degradation of carbons in carboxylic acids, esters, lignin phenolic, and β-O-4 structures. The reduction in peak intensity at 84.1 ppm and 72.3 ppm reflects the amorphous region of cellulose and the partial conversion or removal of hemicellulose. Meanwhile, the intensities of the peaks at 104.3 ppm (C1), 88.4 ppm (C4), and 65.1 ppm (C6) increased following treatment, indicating a reduction in the amorphous regions and a relative increase in the crystalline regions of cellulose in the sugarcane bagasse. Furthermore, new peaks appeared in the residue at 115.8 ppm and 146.8 ppm, indicating changes in the aromatic carbons of residual lignin and the presence of new methoxy compounds at 56.1 ppm [37]. These results suggest that cellulose and hemicellulose in sugarcane bagasse undergo conversion or leaching during solid acid-induced hydrothermal treatment. XRD was used to determine the crystallinity index (CrI) of both untreated and hydrothermally treated sugarcane bagasse to evaluate changes in cellulose crystallinity. The XRD analysis of raw sugarcane bagasse reveals (Fig. 11 ) prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 15.6° (101), 22.1° (002), and 34.4° (040), which correspond to the crystalline planes of cellulose. The calculated crystallinity index (CrI) is 37.6%. After hydrothermal treatment, these peaks remain at the same positions but display increased intensity, especially at 22.1°, indicating an enhancement of cellulose crystalline regions and an elevated CrI value of 43.7%. These results suggest that the hydrothermal process effectively removes amorphous fractions, thereby increasing the relative content of crystalline cellulose. This finding aligns well with the NMR data, which also shows a reduction in the amorphous portion alongside a rise in crystallinity. 3.5 Mechanistic Studies The Fe3O4@PDA-Sn catalyst demonstrated a synergistic effect between its active sites for the one-pot conversion of hemicellulose and cellulose in sugarcane bagasse, leading to enhanced selectivity and carbon efficiency for the target products. Initially, the β-(1→4) glycosidic bonds in hemicellulose undergo Brønsted acid-catalyzed hydrolysis to liberate xylose. The liberated xylose is then isomerized to xylulose at the Lewis acid sites (SnOₓ) via a 1,2-enediol intermediate. Finally, xylulose undergoes dehydration at the Brønsted acid sites (–SO3H and –COOH) to yield furfural. Evidence for the deconstruction of the lignocellulosic backbone during this process was provided by SEM and XRD analyses, which revealed changes in surface morphology and crystallinity, respectively. Concurrently, cellulose was converted to levulinic acid (LA) through a sequential, multi-step process. First, cellulose underwent Brønsted acid-catalyzed hydrolysis to yield glucose monomers. These monomers were then isomerized to fructose at the SnOₓ Lewis acid sites. Subsequently, fructose was dehydrated to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which, in the final step, was rehydrated and cleaved under Brønsted acid catalysis to form LA. This comprehensive degradation of the polysaccharide structure was corroborated by solid-state NMR and FTIR analyses, which showed a marked attenuation of characteristic peaks for carbonyl, ester, and glycosidic bonds. 3.6 Conclusion The valorization of lignocellulosic biomass into high-value platform chemicals requires integrated processes that can simultaneously convert hemicellulose and cellulose while tackling catalyst recovery challenges. This study developed a magnetic Fe3O4@PDA-Sn-catalyzed hydrothermal process for the one-pot conversion of sugarcane bagasse into furfural (86.2% yield) and levulinic acid (LA, 32.5% yield) under optimized conditions (170°C for 90 min) using a NaCl/DCM (1:1) biphasic solvent system. The dual-acid catalyst facilitated selective fractionation: hemicellulose-derived xylose underwent dehydration to furfural via Brønsted/Lewis acid synergy, while cellulose was hydrolyzed to LA through glucose intermediates, achieving a total carbon efficiency of 73.4%. Mechanistic studies revealed that the SnOx Lewis acid sites facilitated xylose isomerization and glucose dehydration, while sulfonic and carboxylic Brønsted acid groups drove dehydration and hydration steps, with the NaCl/DCM system suppressing side reactions through in situ furfural extraction and salting-out effects. Although LA yields were limited by cellulose crystallinity, the catalyst maintained over 74% initial activity across five cycles without regeneration, and furfural retained 84% of its initial activity, which was attributed to its magnetic core-enabled recovery and polydopamine-stabilized active sites. This work establishes a sustainable paradigm for lignocellulose biorefining, linking high product selectivity with closed-loop catalyst reuse, while highlighting the need for pretreatment strategies to overcome biomass recalcitrance in integrated conversion systems. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic biomass conversion is a crucial pathway for high-value utilization of renewable resources, yet current catalysts face limitations such as insufficient acid sites, poor product selectivity, and low cycling stability. This study developed a magnetic tin-based solid acid catalyst (Fe3O4@PDA-Sn) using 5-sulfoisophthalic acid sodium salt as a ligand and dopamine hydrochloride-coated Fe3O4 for targeted catalytic conversion of sugarcane bagasse. Results demonstrated that the catalyst achieved a furfural yield of 86.2% and a levulinic acid yield of 32.5% at 170°C for 90 min, with FT-IR, NMR, and XRD confirming its differential deconstruction capability toward cellulose and hemicellulose. Mechanistic analysis demonstrated that the coordinated interaction between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites played a crucial role in steering the reaction toward specific pathways: hemicellulose hydrolysis products underwent dehydration to furfural (enriched in the organic phase), while cellulose was selectively cleaved to form levulinic acid. The catalyst maintained stable performance over 5 cycles without regeneration, with 97.3% magnetic recovery efficiency, offering a novel "facile magnetic separation–excellent cycling performance" strategy for hierarchical biomass conversion. This work provides critical insights into the design of multifunctional biorefinery catalysts for sustainable biomass valorization.
